questions.question:
Question 1: A forceps delivery is being planned for a patient with prolonged second stage of labour. 
Which of the following is not a prerequisite for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Completely dilated cervix is a prerequisite for forceps delivery. Prerequisites for forceps delivery: • Experienced operator • Engaged head • Ruptured membranes • Vertex presentation • Completely dilated cervix 265 
Sold by @itachibot • Precisely assessed fetal head position • Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspected • Absent fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder Before operative vaginal delivery, the bladder should be emptied to provide additional pelvic 
space and minimize bladder trauma.

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following are criteria for the use of the following instrument except:

options.a: Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
options.b: Fetal head is on the perineum
options.c: Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
options.d: Rotation of fetal head is more than 45 degrees

questions.explanation:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is a type of outlet forceps. Rotation of the fetal head 
should not exceed 45 degrees for the application of outlet forceps. This is because it increases the 
risk of vaginal wall lacerations.

questions.question:
Question 3: 260 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is true about instrumental vaginal delivery?

options.a: Full cervical dilatation is the only prerequisite
options.b: Forceps can be used for delivery of the after-coming head of breech
options.c: Ventouse cannot be used in rotational occipitotransverse/ posterior delivery
options.d: Engaged head is not a prerequisite

questions.explanation:
Forceps can be used for delivery of the aftercoming head of breech. The advantages are as follows: • Delivery can be controlled by giving pull directly on the head and the force is not transmitted 
through the neck. • Flexion is better maintained. • Mucus can be sucked out from the mouth more effectively. Prerequisites for instrumental vaginal delivery: • Ruptured membranes vertex presentation • Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspected • No fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder • Completely dilated cervix • Precisely assessed fetal head position • Engaged head • Experienced operator Note: Ventouse can be used for occipitotranverse or posterior position.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 25-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation is wheeled into the labour room following the 
onset of labor. A forceps delivery is planned for her. Which of the following is not a 
contraindication for this?
questions.explanation:
Forceps can be used to deliver a preterm baby where it is believed to form a protective cage. 
Vacuum is contraindicated in these cases. Contraindications of forceps delivery: • Unengaged head 266 
Sold by @itachibot • Cephalopelvic disproportion • Malpresentations like brow and face (mentoposterior position) • Cervix not completely dilated • Inability to define position • Fetal coagulopathy or osteogenesis imperfecta Note: Forceps delivery is only reserved for mentoanterior position.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the given device used for?
questions.explanation:
The image shown is a vacuum delivery system. It is used for vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery of 
the fetus. Theoretical advantages of ventouse (vacuum extraction) compared to forceps include: • Simpler requirements for positioning of the fetal head • Avoidance of space occupying blades within the vagina • Lower maternal trauma rates

questions.question:
Question 6: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse was planned for ventouse 
delivery. Which statement is true regarding the mode of delivery planned for this patient?

options.a: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are frequently seen
options.b: It can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine
options.c: Maternal trauma is seen more frequently when compared to forceps
options.d: It cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated

questions.explanation:
Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequently seen with 
ventouse delivery than with forceps delivery. Maternal morbidity is seen more with forceps deliveries and perinatal morbidity is seen more with 
vacuum deliveries. Maternal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include: • Increased third and fourth-degree vaginal lacerations • Pelvic floor disorders • Postpartum hemorrhage Perinatal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include: • Vacuum-assisted perinatal injuries: Cephalohematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, retinal 
hemorrhage, neonatal jaundice secondary to these hemorrhages, shoulder dystocia, clavicular 
fracture, intracranial hemorrhage, and scalp lacerations. • Forceps-assisted perinatal injuries: Higher rates of facial nerve injury, brachial plexus injury, 
depressed skull fracture, and corneal abrasion. In cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. It is conducted with the laboring woman in an 
upright or left decubitus position. Prophylactic use of vacuum is done to cut short the second 
stage of labor. This is to minimize aortocaval compression. Caesarean section is not preferred 
since it is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk. 267 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Contraindications of ventouse include all except:
questions.explanation:
Deep transverse arrest is an indication for ventouse delivery. In ventouse delivery technique, suction is created within a cup placed on the fetal scalp such that 
traction on the cup aids fetal expulsion. The important step in ventouse extraction is proper cup 
placement over the flexion point. The vacuum is gradually created by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 
minutes until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached. Progressive descent should 
accompany each traction attempt.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida in labor. 
The obstetrician planned for a ventouse delivery because of maternal exhaustion. She asked 
you to help place the ventouse cup. Where would you place it?

options.a: On the sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
options.b: On the sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior fontanelle
options.d: On the coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle

questions.explanation:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. It is a 
point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. Advantages of correct positioning of cup in vacuum extraction: • Maximum traction • Minimum cup detachment • Twisting of fetal head is avoided • Smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet • Success rate is improved • Fetal scalp injury rates are lowered • Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva 268 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 24-year-old term primigravida was brought to the hospital in labor. Prophylactic ventouse 
was used due to ineffective expulsive efforts by the mother. What is the maximum negative 
pressure used in this procedure? 262 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The maximum negative pressure used in ventouse is 0.8 kg/cm2 Gradual vacuum creation is recommended. This is generated by increasing the suction in 
increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes. This is done until a total negative pressure of 0.8 
kg/cm2 is reached. This slow incremental approach would allow for a more firm attachment of the vacuum cup to the 
fetal head and thereby a lower failure rate.

questions.question:
Question 10: A prophylactic ventouse was planned for an anaemic pregnant woman. Delivery through this 
mode should occur within 
.
questions.explanation: Delivery with ventouse should occur within 3 pulls over 15-20 min.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 24-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by assisted forceps delivery. What 
is not an advantage of this mode of delivery?

options.b: Quick in case of fetal distress

questions.explanation: Autorotation is seen with vacuum extraction and not assisted forceps delivery. Advantages of ventouse over forceps: • No need of anaesthesia • Less expertise required • Less maternal injuries • Promotes autorotation • Does not occupy the sides • Less traction force needed Advantages of forceps over ventouse: • No maternal effort is needed • Quick in case of fetal distress • Can be used in face and breech • Can be used in preterm • Less cephalohematoma • Delivery failure is less

questions.question: Question 12: What is the advantage of ventouse over forceps?

options.c: Can be used in preterm head

questions.explanation:
The advantage of ventouse over forceps is that less expertise is required in this technique. Advantages of ventouse over forceps: 269 
Sold by @itachibot • No need of anaesthesia • Less expertise required • Less maternal injuries • Promotes autorotation • Does not occupy the sides • Less traction force needed Advantages of forceps over ventouse: • No maternal effort is needed • Quick in case of fetal distress • Can be used in face and breech • Can be used in preterm • Less cephalohematoma • Delivery failure is less

questions.question:
Question 13: 263 
Sold by @itachibot During a routine check-up of a multigravida at 32 weeks of gestation, the fetus was found to 
be in breech presentation. The obstetrician planned to do an external cephalic version. What 
is the ideal time to do this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The ideal time to do external cephalic version is 37 weeks. This procedure is attempted in a 
woman who has completed 36 weeks of gestation and has a breech fetal presentation. Before 37 weeks, a breech presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously. 
Moreover, if performed too early, there is time to return back to breech. After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early 
stages of labour, it is not recommended.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 25-year-old multigravida at 36 weeks presents for routine ANC. On examination, a hard, 
ballotable structure is felt at the fundus. NST is reactive. The obstetrician performs the 
following procedure on her. When will this procedure be contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
The procedure shown here is external cephalic version. A relative contraindication for this 
procedure is intra-uterine growth restriction.

questions.question: Question 15: At which angle would you perform a mediolateral episiotomy in a primigravida?
questions.explanation:
The mediolateral episiotomy is directed at an angle of 60 degrees. The mediolateral episiotomy incision starts in the midline at the fourchette and is directed at an 
angle 60 degrees from the midline. This 60-degree angle takes into consideration a distortion of 
perineal anatomy during crowning and ultimately yields an incision that is 45 degrees from the 
midline following delivery. 270 
Sold by @itachibot 271 
Sold by @itachibot Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesarean (VBAC)
